150070029.review:
[b]EST Completion Time (1 Playthrough):[/b] 10 minutes
[b]Achievements Available:[/b] 2
[b]EST Completion Time (100% Achievements):[/b] 10 minutes
[b]Trading Cards Available:[/b] 0 (N/A)

[h1]Overview[/h1]
[i]Carpe Diem[/i] is an incredibly short kinetic visual novel about setting the right priorities in life, using your time wisely, and seizing the day (hence [i]Carpe Diem[/i]). The game, which is essentially a prequel to [i]Carpe Diem: Reboot[/i], presents itself as a mundane slice-of-life story in which you play as Jung, [spoiler]a programmer who has created an artificial world[/spoiler], who spends the day with his “perfect girl,” Ai. Unfortunately, due to [spoiler]Ai being actual artificial intelligence (AI)[/spoiler], you have limited time to spend with her and can only attend 2 of the 3 locations within 1 playthrough ([spoiler]Mall + Arcade, Park + Mall, or Arcade + Park[/spoiler]) – which enforces the idea of strategically allocating your time with activities you want to do and wasting none of it on trying to do everything.

Regardless of how Jung chooses to spend their day with Ai, the path chosen is ultimately irrelevant as the ending is the same: an unsurprising reveal that [spoiler]Ai is AI[/spoiler] accompanied by a lackluster explanation of [spoiler]the Turing Test[/spoiler] ([spoiler]an “evaluation of a machine’s ability to exhibit intelligence and whether it can act or speak like a human”[/spoiler]). Somewhat shamefully, the game does itself a disservice by foreshadowing too obviously that the content will examine [spoiler]artificial intelligence and philosophy[/spoiler]; whereas if the characters had different names and players were unsuspecting than perhaps we would’ve had the genuine “WOW!” moment that the developers seemingly hoped for. Much like other forms of art and expression, if a game needs to explain its point and purpose in the end, then it failed to convey its point and purpose throughout the game itself.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
[i]Carpe Diem[/i] is an incredibly short, free-to-play kinetic visual novel that sets the stage for [i]Carpe Diem: Reboot[/i]. If you’re interested in its sequel and/or quickly scoring an easy 100% and 2 achievements, than it’s worth the short playthrough; otherwise, invest your 10 minutes of free time elsewhere.

144352435.review:
In [i]„Carpe Diem“[/i] we are playing as the MC who has a date with Ai, a female friend which he hasn't seen lately. At the end of the day our lovebirbs are watching a romantic firework together and as the usual shoujo-enjoyer you would expect a confession now however it's time for another kind of reveal. Ai is basically an A.I and therefore not real.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3021175398

Nah, it doesn't work. If you plan to drop a plot twist on the players please at least take some of your time to develop the right setting for it. Prepare a flashed-out story with engaging characters, terrific dialogues and watch the tension slowly building up till it stabs us right in the back when we at at least expect it.
 
[i]„A beautiful mind“[/i] does an excellent job at catching the viewers off-guard, the short animation film [i]„Best Friend“ [/i] straight-up tells us about the existence of this „parallel world“ which works wonderfully as it digs deeper into the story with this piece of information at the back of our mind.

Tell my why [strike] ain't nothing than a heart ache[/strike] should I even care about this plottwist, it is not like I am anything involved in the story yet or even build up a connection to anyone. Jun is flat-out boring and I can't pinpoint if he is intended to come off this way or if it is just a slip-up from the writer's side. Meanwhile Ai is somewhat okayish but all her dialogue follows the same pattern:

> teasing him in a lame way
> MC responds in an equally lame taunt
> feisty response while blushing

Overall there isn't much to say as I spent more time writing this review than actually playing however I would like to note that just because a game is free to play doesn't give it a free pass to present us a poorly delivered story and getting away with it.

102058174.review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34294631/] Follow Far2close - Visual Novel Playthroughs Curator Page [/url]
Carpe Diem
Developer: Moonlit Works
Publisher: Moonlit Works

[b]Pros:[/b]
[b]1.[/b] The story is simple and short, just you hanging out with your friend for the day. You can choose which place to go to such as the park, mall, or arcade, all with their fitting dialogue for each section. It is a pretty wholesome plot nonetheless and the ending does pack a bit of a surprise as it somewhat leads to Carpe Diem: Reboot.
[b]2.[/b] The art had taken an overhaul compared to its 2015 look, from the main menu to the overall graphics throughout, it is a good change. The menu image is clean and aesthetically minimalistic along with Ai taking on a more polished look with different outfits and facial expressions.
[b]3.[/b] The music consists of upbeat tones along with cheerful piano elements, but when a mood change is needed, in comes the more melancholic piano track to help emphasize the sadness of a scene.




[b]Cons:[/b]
[b]1.[/b] The plot is nearly nonexistent other than the ending providing a hint of lore.
[b]2.[/b] The art has been upgraded, but Ai does lack some different poses.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
A benign but almost nonexistent story, it is a decent introduction to Ai and Jung that is recommended but not exactly necessary for the sequel, "Carpe Diem: Reboot".



[b]Score:[/b] 6/10 DECENT

99591341.review:
Carpe Diem is a really short, but sweet anime visual novel about Jung going to hang out with his friend Ai.

You get to play as Jung and decide where to take Ai first on your date. I chose Arcade, but anywhere is fine! You set off and get to read along to the story and advance with clicking (or enter maybe, but I don't know; I didn't test it). 

Shortly after the gaming adventure, my story went to food, then the park. Hanging out and sharing what they've been up to since they haven't seen each other for awhile. 

You get to experience a small romance (jealousy included - even if minor), the positivity and happiness of a good friendship. 

The only thing left is the twist - which I can say for once actually surprised me - even with it being so obvious! My baaaad!

I really enjoyed this; it was cute and pleasing for such a short game. I recommend it if you want to take a few minutes and get a story in, or just like to play visual novels!

Graphics were great - I LOVED the starry sky - and the music was a nice additive. Story is short but sweet.

You can see my whole review with game stats here: https://jaderexeverythingsite.wordpress.com/2021/09/20/carpe-diem-game-review/

87694639.review:
It just hit me: This game, Carpe Diem, reminds me of the season 5 episode 1 of Arthur. You start this game being told to spend your time wisely. The episode begins with Arthur's friends rejoicing at Arthur being a big loser. Arthur says "You can be a big loser too!" and he asks the viewer a riddle: "When is it better to be a loser than a winner?" The rest of the episode is Arthur in a game show. At the end of the Carpe Diem the common reaction is either "Wow" or "This game trolled me." Near the episodes' end Arthur asks if the viewer got the riddle right. The episode then ends with Arthur saying: "I hope not, because if you did, you're watching too many game shows!" And then the viewer remembers that Arthur said "You can be a big loser too!" Therefore, either way, the viewer is a big loser because either they got the riddle wrong and was a big loser in regards to the riddle (And they don't watch too many game shows) or they got it right (and they have been watching too many game shows so they are a big loser). Either way, both Arthur and Moonlit Works/Eyzi (the developer) is right and the viewer is wrong but it is good because not only does the viewer learn something but real life and reality is shown. In short, lesson learned, like it or not. Better learn the lessons than not - for they are true. That's why its called reality. I was grateful at the end of this game and I liked the ending of that episode of Arthur. The question is: at the end are you going to be angry or grateful?
At the end of Carpe Diem, if you were angry, remember this quote from the movie The Princess Bride: 
"Life IS pain, Highness. Anyone who says differently is selling something."

74022918.review: One of those games that you're not sure whether to recommend or not. On the whole, it's a perfectly harmless piece of fluff that is absolutely adequate for a free game. The couple of music tracks are fine. The handful of facial expressions on the sprite are alright. The backgrounds are entirely serviceable. The writing and dialogue are unremarkable but perfectly acceptable.  But it's honestly not that engaging, for all of the 15 minutes it takes to run through it once. There's nothing wrong with slice-of-life as a genre at all, but you do have to do something more with it to stand out. I suppose the ending, which I won't spoil, moves that along a bit. I would say that it opens up more possibilities and I wouldn't mind seeing more of this story with that in mind, but this feels like prologue for the sequel that I know exists. And that's fine. It's free. On the whole if you want a cutesy bit of slice-of-life to breeze through, you'll like it, and maybe be interested in the sequel. But if you want anything more in-depth, this obviously isn't the game for you.

72913386.review:
What are you doing with your life?

[h1]Story[/h1]
Carpe Diem is a very short VN created by Moonlit Works. You are a character named Jung who is on a date with a girl named Ai. You could go to the mall, park or arcade. The choice is yours. [spoiler]But does it all matter since she isn't real? What are you doing with your life?[/spoiler] How will you spend your day with Ai? What will go on during your date? [spoiler]Do these questions even matter?[/spoiler]

[h1]Positives[/h1]
Since this is very short, we don't really get to learn much about the characters. However, they play their part well. While all we know of Jung is that his living conditions are that well, Ai is a girl who likes spiders, is very talkative and competitive. While the title screen isn't much, I do like the clever use of the "a" in Carpe and the "i" in Diem to spell her name out. That was clever. The choices are nice, though you will have the same ending. The backgrounds look nice and the background music is good. Ai's art is good and she has a few expressions, so that's neat. [spoiler]The ending got me. I wasn't expecting it all to be a test and Ai wasn't real. It was really unexpected. I get her name was Ai which is almost the same as AI or Artificial Intelligence, but I never thought of that. Very clever, game devs. Very clever. [/spoiler]

[h1]Negatives/Nitpicks[/h1]
- There was no save button in sight. The only thing is a quicksave button. Even though this game is very short (for me, it was shorter than Adolescent Santa Claus, a VN I completed in 33 minutes. I took even less time with this one), it would have been nice to have it.
- We don't get to learn much about the characters, but...
are we supposed to?

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Carpe Diem is a nice VN. While the characters aren't developed and the length is very short, it's fine for what it is. It's a free VN to put some free time into when you have the chance. It's a decent VN [spoiler]with an ending that most wouldn't expect[/spoiler]that I can recommend.

65642137.review:
After reading some comments I've expected something much harsher, but still didn't disappointed me tbh. 
Game is VERY short... I mean like 10 minute short. It's a tiny game tho, so can't complain. 
So, what is it like? 
I will try to avoid spoilers 
Good Points: 
* Game just looks good. Ai is very nicely painted, not many details, but it works! 
* Music, even tho it feels like it's very generic, I think it's actually very good for this game. Just gives that extra something to the ending.

*** Plot Twist, it's not like the biggest one I've ever seen, but it hits you when you don't expect it. Many in comments say it makes them think, about life, and how they are and all that stuff... And I'm not gonna lie, I can imagine that as it's definitely a game that makes you question, "what I'm doing with my life?". Even tho I'm not really into VNs or anime games, or even games in general, and I'm looking for something to do during quarantine (corona lol), but it still makes me think about life. 

Bad Points
*Tbh, I don't think there are any... Fact that it's extremely short? Some could say that it makes them feel like a looser... but let's be honest guys... If you feel like a looser after playing this game... Than maybe you should consider a change? Cuz after all, that seems to be the whole point of this novel. Get out, enjoy life... find new hobbies. 

Overall?
Well, I love it me... Good story, character is cute and etc... I guess it's hard to fuck up 10 minute game. But it's brilliant. 
I believe it can hook you into the world of VN.

Now, play it... and go get a life lol

65431069.review:
This is a cute little game that could more or less serve as an introduction to visual novels for people who haven't played ones before, especially being free. If you enjoyed this one and want to continue the story, Carpe Diem: Reboot tells a great story that may be enjoyed by people who liked this one.

[b]Visuals[/b]:
The graphics are pretty nice. With the 2020 update, they add a nicer feel to the game, and make it seem a little better than it was prior.

[b]Voice Acting[/b]:
There is no voice acting in this Vis Nov

[b]Characters[/b]:
Ai is a pretty cute character, and you get to know her a little if you pay attention.
I've seen a lot of reviews comment on this, so I figured I'd put my input on it as well. While the name 'Ai' could be read as AI, Ai is a common Japanese name meaning 'Love,' and with the little context in this game alone, could be a perfectly valid name.

[b]Story[/b]:
Short, sweet, and to the point. It follows the 'cute' theme that I noticed through the whole game.

[b]Comedy[/b]:
There's not a whole lot of comedy, but it's played in a natural way. If you're picky about your comedy like I am, I wouldn't get this game for the comedy.

[b]Music[/b]:
It's not fantastic, but it gets the idea across, and doesn't get annoying.

[b]Conclusion[/b]:
This is a cute little vis nov that I recommend for people who are new to vis novs, kind of like a trial, or dipping your toes in. The sequel is better in every regard, and isn't expensive. If this one peaked your interest, I'd recommend spending the $6 to get it.

Carpe Diem is a relatively easy and digestible visual novel that I quite enjoyed. I originally played through this game three weeks after it’s initial release back in December 2015, nearly half a decade ago now. The story isn’t great by any means, it has it’s flaws granted but that doesn’t get in the way too much of the overall story it has set out to tell, it’s overtly simple and has a twist that I have still yet to see replicated elsewhere, which does give it a flavoured stroke of uniqueness. I do have to say I am terribly thankful for the 2020 update towards the art assets and music as from what I can recall each of those were positively ghastly upon release, especially when compared to most visual novels available on the market at the time. Now with the improved art assets an updated music I am much more inclined to recommend this product to others, I personally believe that this update was far too much of a long time coming in fairness however the new musical score makes it worth it as it is no longer a blight on the ears, seriously that monotonous loop every minute and a half was terrible. That being said I do have to note that the dialogue within this project is still quite dull, personally I cannot shake the feeling that the developer had never actually engaged in a conversation with a woman in his life, but this does lean in favour and actually help the main character and his goals towards the end. On top of that the dialogue options are essentially pointless and offer absolutely no sense of proper replayability to the table which is a shame in and of itself realistically speaking. It is to my understanding that the reason for this to an extent is due to the fact that this story is a prologue of sorts, which at the time of writing I have yet to play, so I can’t say anything about it’s relations towards its sequel of sorts I am sorry to say. All in all I really liked this game, this is mostly due to that 2020 update the devs decided to give it in fairness, but being a veteran of sorts to this genre I can say the uniqueness is also a factor into my initial settlement on a recommendation.

54522421.review:
Very enjoyable free and short visual novel that starts out fairly basic but develops into a sweet narrative about friendship/innocent love between a guy and a girl and ends in an unexpected way.

There are just two characters, Jung (the player) and Ai, a girl that guides you trough the VN.

There is just one choice which branches the very short story into three fairly similar routes.

The character art is really nice to look at but limited in animation and the background art is really basic but serviceable.

Background music consists of two soft piano songs, that can get a little bit repetitive, but since one walktrough doesn't take more than 15 minutes, it didn't bother me as much.

I played through all the "routes" in about 30 minutes and tried different languages.
Sadly there are some typos in the english and german version.

Worth trying out if you like short Visual Novels and have some time to spare.

51640980.review: I, absolutely love this game. It has its flaws, (forced feel to the story, a little linear at times and only truly free and sandboxy when you complete the game, and this is most definitely the game I've had the most trouble launching as it freezes a lot on startup with discord overlay enabled) but I still love it. A lot. Once the story is all said and done, (story is well done by the way, just takes away some of your freedom if you want to make another character and have to sit through it again) it's incredibly open ended. Wanna go explore some caves? You can do that. Wanna go explore the one or two kinds of planets you don't encounter by doing the story? Strap on a appropriate EPP for the weather and go crazy. And the mods. My god, this community is up there with Team Fortress 2 and Garry's Mod with the quality of the workshop items. Some fans have even done what Chucklefish hasn't bothered to. Patched bugs and glitches that were a hindrance to the overall experience. Overall, even with the flaws that this game has (including one I forget to mention, Chucklefish seems to have forgotten about it and have since stopped pushing updates as far as I know), it's still an enjoyable experience. The story is well written (though sometimes drags along), and once you're done with the story, the entire Galaxy is yours to explore. Replay value on different characters doesn't really exist, but staying with one you like and staying in that world, never gets old. Hell, I only have around 30 hours as of now but I'm still always hooked and find something to do. Looking past the somewhat linear story, and seeing the wonderful community and freedom after the story that this game has to offer, give it a shot. It's a god damn amazing game.

Carpe Diem feels as though it was a "my first development title" kind of visual novel. There was an idea behind it, but it never fleshed into anything more than the finale of it, which in turn felt like a beginning to a much larger story. It's incredibly short, but it's free. 

I can't really recommend it, except if maybe you're interested in the sequel "Reboot" which actually seems like a longer, more fleshed out novel. As it is, it isn't really enjoyable as it's own experience and own story, but just something to take in context of the sequel.

50380646.review:
As a life-long player of choose-your-own-adventure gamebooks, I enjoyed this. I'm new to the visual novel sub-genre, so I figured I'd try a brief one to see how I liked it, as a test of the concept. [u]Carpe Diem[/u] starts [i]in medias res[/i], and so some of one's energy as a player is taken up with just figuring out what's going on and who's who. Part of that is figuring out who YOU are, as the story is told in first person: unusual in a video game. The game does give you some hints, and I was pleasantly surprised to find psychology references show up in a free video game. [spoiler]The main character is Jung, named after Carl Jung, early psychologist who developed the concept of the unconscious. The main character's interest is in Ai, which is clever in that it is both pronounced "I" as in self (the ego) and literally the letters A.I. for artificial intelligence. It's a little on the nose, but it works well with the in medias res approach.[/spoiler]
The interchange between the characters is fun, although the format leaves a bit to be desired in terms of expressing the emotions behind the words. The visuals consist of a static background to indicate the location, and a semi-static image of the girl Ai in that location. Her facial expressions change to broadly suggest her feelings at each line's delivery, but you get no such clues for the main character, Jung. So there's more work to try to fathom whether he's being sarcastic or literal, teasing or oblivious. The clues are there in the text - it's written pretty well - but it's like watching a movie for one character's part of the conversation and having to read a script for the other character's lines. To put it another way - in the context of video games - Ai's dialogue is like playing "7th Guest" while Jung's lines are like playing "Zork." That may not be unique to this visual novel - it may be a common feature of the genre - but it's still strange and new to me. But I liked it; deciphering the intent of the text was a bit like a puzzle to me. And the puzzle was made more complicated by the nature and context of the conversations, as they are so foreign to me, being a married father. [spoiler]Though of course, there's a reason for that: the theme of alienation is very strong in this story; it is central to the plot, after all. So it would be a little weird if someone were to play the game and think "This is just a slice of life story. I just had a date with my imaginary computer girlfriend just like it."[/spoiler] Overall I enjoyed this game more than I feared I would. It encourages me to try out other visual novels to see how others approach the format.

48955593.review:
This game is absolutely horrid.

I've never wasted my time in a more unproductive way.  I'm so sad I ever knew of the existence of this game ever. Here's why.

There is a single choice that you make in this 10-20 minute game. It's just the one showed in the trailer, where you want to take "Ai." Then, you get a total of about 3 backgrounds and 3 different and reused facial expressions for the rest of the game. There was no backstory, no storyline, had no idea throughout the duration of the game why I was there, who I was, who she was, how we knew each other, why we knew each other, nothing. You're just thrown into this "universe" (more of a poorly drawn background of a park that's literally reused later on) with no context whatsoever. The dialogue is disgusting. So cringy, so forced, so easy to come up with, EXTREMELY cliche lines. Not to mention I literally predicted how the game would end before I even pressed play.

I had a friend play it, even got my MOTHER to play this game. It wasn't even a means of torturing them, so I kinda feel bad, but I needed someone to feel the pain that I did. Both of them absolutely hated it and felt disappointed, saddened, and frustrated. This game truly was an insult to my intelligence. To see how far I could make it before I just quit and started sobbing. But I persevered through this horrible story and lived to tell the tale. Despite all this, and despite that I do not recommend it, maybe you should play too, because now I probably have caught your curiosity as to why this game is such an abomination to everything we once knew. Hopefully you live to tell the tale. Good luck if you choose to play this soldier, make sure to recommend to your worst enemies so they too can suffer and live the rest of their life knowing that they wasted a good 15 minutes of their life. Thank you for reading.

47846341.review:
A fairly boring date followed by a twist ending. The twist isn't really incorporated into the story, more just told to the player in a few lines at the end. Ever heard of "show, don't tell"? Spoiler: [spoiler]The whole date was inside a computer, and I was Turing test the whole time.[/spoiler] When a spoiler is that short, it's not that great of a surprise anyway. You can probably guess the ending by looking at the title of the game. The whole thing is an interesting idea but executed poorly. See Doki Literature Club to see basically the same idea done right.

Somehow, despite how simple the "twist" is that is abruptly explained to you at the end, it isn't explained well. Why does she have, tragically, only one day to live? Maybe she learns too much in the time that she's alive that the computer doesn't have enough memory to continue to simulate her? Did you try restarting the computer? I don't know, I just came up with that in like 5 seconds, why didn't the author put a tiny but of effort into what is the crux, the only interesting thing, about the whole story?

If you're going to play the game, I just recommend not going to the arcade on the first playthrough. There is like one line on the other routes that provide a tiny bit of foreshadowing that greatly enhances the culpability of the idea. Most of it is filler material in which you are "on a date," though.

meanwhile Real life is filled with amazing people, fun and love.... sure there is drama all over the place and so what? you thought it would be easy? Nah mate. ¨pain today writes poems¨, and sure there are hell lots of poems to write, and the most important one... LIFE

Maybe reincarnation is true maybe the afterlife is true or maybe no... You want to find out? And when you do so 60-70 years later look back and think ´´That was all? i didnt had time i didnt experience it all, everything is just... over!``

isnt that a magnificent way to go?

what are you doing with your life?

This is a short review of the free visual novel game "Carpe Diem".  I hope this helps!~

Game Rating: 4.5/5.0

Time spent playing: 1.8 hours. (Including a replay and some time AFK, so it's probably closer to 15 - 30 minutes for every 'area'....)

Pros:

1. Cute anime art style
2. Easy to read writing which also happens to be interesting and fun enough to keep reading.
3. It's free.

Neutral Points:

1. Only one ending. This isn't really good or bad, so I'm putting it here.
2. Very short.

Cons:

1. The ending may be somewhat predictable, with  [spoiler] Ai being an A.I. as the name suggests [/spoiler]

Overall opinion: While I'd like to see this game expanded upon, it's still fun on its own. It can definitely be completed in one sitting and it's free, so try the game out for yourself if you're into short VNs.

43664086.review:
Обновлено: 16 июн в 11:07

Introduction
Carpe Diem is a very, very short Indie visual novel that's pretty fresh in terms of story but the game itself is very short that can be completed in less than an hour or even less.

Story(NO SPOILERS) & Gameplay
In the visual story, you play as Jung, your typical everyday adult guy who has a date with a her ideal woman, Ai, who has everything he wishes for in a woman. Storywise, it's pretty decent and solid but to others and newcomers, it may feel like the story is rushed and not much story-branching is not really impacting the story especially when the ending does not change at all (as mentioned on the store page). Some players might also feel that, the ending, although sad to hear, feels abrupt and out of nowhere. For the developer's first step, it's a fine step (coming from someone who doesn't develop games LOL) for the developer, however visual novel die-hards may find this to be rushed. Overall, story is fine except that it can feel really short and abrupt, especially towards the ending. And no, the ending does not in a cliffhanger so you don't need to play the sequel, Carpe Diem:Reboot.

Visuals
Visuals look pretty good, especially for the developer's first visual novel.The colours give the locations a personality and definetely make Ai look very pretty. Other than that, there's not too much to say for a game that's very short, So yeah, visuals look good and nice.

Soundtrack
The music sounds very calming and relaxing. However, after listening to a couple of times, it may get pretty repititive and somewhat annoying. There isn't much in terms of music. 3 Soundtracks in total: Main game, ending and the menu (I think, if there's one;cant remember lol). Overall, nice music but can get pretty reptitive (which shouldn't be the case for a very short game).

Conclusion
Carpe Diem is a solid direction for the developer's first visual novel, which makes it interesting for casual visual novel players to join. However, its short story and abrupt ending can turn serious visual novel players off. But regardless, it shows a message to players that it is important to keep your 
priorities to your loved ones.

Pros
+Nice visuals
+Relaxing soundtrack
+Short to complete

Cons
-Very short
-Abrupt ending
-Music can be repititive

Rating
6/10

43606541.review:
A rather short visual novel. You play as a guy named Jung who spends a day with his good friend/love interest Ai--the twist is that [spoiler]Ai is literally her name. She's an artificial intelligence created by Jung that he is testing the sentience of[/spoiler]. Each of the three storylines are equally about five minutes long (about fifteen minutes total), so like I said, it's pretty short.

Although there isn't much point to playing this game other than to set up for the sequel, "Carpe Diem: Reboot", it really gives a profound perspective of considering what we do with our everyday lives. We never know when it will end for us, so we shouldn't waste the time we've been given.

So with that, I say: [i]Carpe Diem.[/i] [i]Seize the day.[/i]

[b]Content Warning(s):[/b] None

[b]Final Score:[/b] 7 / 10

43421970.review:
If you're an achievement hunter, you can get 100% with this game's single achievement in about a minute of text skips for the low low price of FREE.

If you're here for the Visual part, you're basically seeing everything there is in the provided screenshots. There are no other backgrounds and there are no other characters. And the only variation you'll see in Ai's character is her face now and then.

If you're here for the Novel part... this is short. Very short. Especially if you're a fast reader. You can try out all 3 'choices' of the only 'branch' you're given in this entire thing and still be done in under half an hour. For what it's worth I'd consider this a Kinetic VN since neither of the choices has any big impact or changes for the story.

I wouldn't exactly call the ending a big twist, but I get where it is coming from I suppose. The rather static art cements the 'reveal' more than anything I'd say.

The music seems more distracting than ambient, especially since it does not reflect changes of scenery or mood, at least not up until the final scene. It is nice and upbeat, but always the same regardless of what location you're at. Then again, it is after all a short game, so it might be part for the course to only have a small music pool for it.


Overall, this game isn't bad by any means. It's free and so in that sense I could tell anyone to give it a try to see for themselves if they got a few minutes to spare. For me, it didn't quite achieve what it set out to do and just lacks a bit of polish here and there. It's not bad, it's just not that good either.

43222686.review:
I can’t be bothered to write a full review for this game since it annoyed me so much with its lazy presentation…

Overly pretentious, and signaling how smart it is… It’s quite clear straight away why the game names its characters Jung and Ai. What it fails to realize is that just invoking such concepts doesn’t actually mean that they’ve been effectively incorporated into the game. It signals the intelligence of its creators but it does not translate well to art which is where intelligence is implied through execution.
This was furtherly annoying since the prose itself is littered with casual euphemisms and banal speech that didn’t elevate the subject matter at all.

The characters are uninteresting, the protagonist, as a blank slate is particularly frustrating as his (or the players) reaction to Ai is not tinted with any level of understanding. It is pedestrian in its own mundanity. Whether this is an issue of playing across a cultural line I am not sure, but somehow considering the bombastic characters that proliferate in other asian stories the character of Jung did not live up to his namesake. 
Ai is also rather dreary, and is no more interesting than a short raising of the eyebrow at the ambiguity implied by her name.

The character interactions are plagued by paradoxes.. this begins at the first meeting where Jung is reprimanded for saying how long he waited (she kept him waiting half an hour!, which he doesn’t even display irritation about) She then informs him he shouldn’t have mentioned how long he waited in an obnoxious display which Jung just seems to allow. She then further insults him by saying of course he couldn’t follow her obnoxious protocol of not mentioning her rudeness since he ‘wouldn’t follow it anyway’. So she about faces from saying he is rude to simply accepting that he did mention her tardiness. I’m not sure if this is normal behavior at all, but as far as I can see its not… the overall tone and seriousness of the characters expressions don’t convey the feeling of light banter, so from the outset the impression of the game is one of jarring discontinuity between actual circumstances and characterization.

The game itself is incredibly short, choices are limited and the story arcs are extremely linear diverging completely and never overlapping or reconverging. It is very simple and somewhat boring to read. There is no tension or conflict to add impetus to the narrative, it is in effect merely describing the meeting of two friends. And the great reveal, holds no weight due to the lack of observation on the aspects of life that should be there.

There is no theme really other than the simple wish fulfillment of a lonely man. There’s no nuance or subtlety in the text to make its audience feel compassion or empathy. This subject matter has been done far better elsewhere. And despite the irony of the title there is really nothing of importance that the game has to say.

The artwork is simplistic. The character of Ai looks quite flat, despite the tones added to her sprite. There is a lack of emphasis to her colour tone that seems sterile, perhaps appropriate considering her role but does not make her interesting. 
Backgrounds are drawn and suffer from irregular perspective lines, lack of texture and at times what looks like a job done in MS Paint. The overall feeling is one that is amateur, and lacks polish and attention to detail. 

Carpe Diem is free, and perhaps its hoping that this should give it a free pass to a recommendation however quality is not always congruent to what one pays, and although this game is free, it is most definitely lacking in quality.

43206005.review:
A boring, pretentious piece of crap. This review contains spoilers, so read onward at your own risk - though I don't see why you'd want to after reading that. Still, if you wanna find out for yourself, go play - but trust me, it's not worth your time.






Still here? Righto.

The girl's not real. She exists only in a program that the protagonist, Jung, is developing. The game ends when it crashes again and he wonders what he's doing with his life. Oh, gee, what a surprise. Yeah, the game tries to be all deep and shit when it's just... not. The description for this visual novel claims that it's "a free short visual (kinetic) novel made to show the importance of setting the right priorities in life," but here's the thing: it never actually [i]shows[/i] the importance of setting the right priorities in life.

We never get to know Jung or the kind of lifestyle he lives beyond being told that this is all a program he develops. But that's far too little information to go on! Is it just something he works on in his spare time? Has he quit his job to devote more time to working on the program? What circumstances led him to begin development on this program? Does he have any friends, family, or other loved ones? Is he does, are his relationships with those people suffering because of the program in some way? We're never told any of these things. All we're told is that he's developing this program to talk to a fictional girl in it, and apparently, that's supposed to be an inherently bad thing.

If you're going to argue that that sort of behavior is ultimately harmful, then at least try to make a convincing case for [i]why[/i] it's harmful and maybe offer some alternatives, rather than just condemning people for having a hobby you don't like. But Carpe Diem doesn't do this. All it amounts to is saying "your waifu isn't real." Oh, gee, I didn't know that. Thank you so much for enlightening me.

Now, to give credit where credit's due, the art is decent, and the music is... Well, it's generic, but it didn't actively make me want to stab my ears with an ice pick. But with visual novels, I like to think of these things as the icing on the cake; they're nice when they're well-done, but they're not going to save a terrible cake from being terrible no matter how good the icing is.

In short, Carpe Diem is a judgemental, pretentious waste of time.

43077287.review: Very short game. I'd say it's worth playing one route (takes about 10-20 minutes) and not doing the rest.

43058519.review:
It's short, corny, mildly amusing, and for absolutely free.

It feels like a demo of the beginning of a summarry of a novel, but still. Not bad for the solid price of 0$. 

(Trust me, I've played WAYYYYYY worse games, even ones that falsely claim to be actual "game" games.)

My favorite part about this story is the fact that it makes no effort to make it seem any more grand or important than it actually is; it's a short, simple mini-story leading up to the real story that is still under development. They didn't try to hype it up as something fantastic, because, to be honest, it's not.

The dev(s) said, and I quote; "This is intended to be a single playthrough kind of novel. The choices all lead to the same ending, just taking different routes." They don't gloss it over by slapping on the pizazz lines like "with a multitude of branching paths for limitless replayability!"

They literally tell you, it's got only one ending, so don't replay it over and over cuz yer not gonna find much of anything new. And by the way, the ending was also kinda funny, and more 4th-wall-breakingly amusing than certain other, more professional titles [spoiler] *coughcoughdokidokiliteratureclubcoughcough* [/spoiler] .

As it stands, in it's current state, this story is terrible, I'll admit. It's a novice work made by a novice dev. But you know what? As a fellow game dev in the making, I fully respect the hard work, determination, and devotion that it takes to produce a truly great videogame. But with time, hard work, determination, and willpower, Carpe Diem could become something great.

The art style is simple, but that adds to the overall atmosphere of simplicity and "budget-title air". The music is peppy, perky, and cheerful, but also sad and mournful, but also calm, at the end. 
The character development is interesting, though could use more time to really flesh them out more. 
The "twist" was not surprising at all, but still. It was slightly emotionally moving, so I'll say good job, cuz it's not easy to forge an emotional bond with a character in such a short time. (Trust me, I've tried to do so with my own short stories before; not as easy as it sounds. Then again, I've got a knack for longer stories and sagas, not short stories.)

PROS:
-It's free
-It takes less than a half hour to finish
-Takes only a second or two to completely download
-Funny "Hidden achievement"
-Ai is kinda cute at times

CONS:
-Insanely short; not even worth the amount of time it takes to look through the options menu
-Feels like a snippet of a demo
-Weak plot shocker
-Cruddy, lackluster environments (not that big of a problem. Again; this isn't a triple-A title, it doesn't really have a fanbase yet, and it has no real consequence for said field's lack thereof. So yeah, not a problem.)
-Only two songs (So far as I remember hearing; again, it just sorta whizzed by me so fast I didn't really stay awhile and listen...)

FINAL VERDICT:
4 of 10. (Needs some work)

I would've given it a lower score, but the dev(s) straightforwardness regarding what this short mininovel truly is is admirable. Plus also, Ai's fighter-mode is adorable. (play it for yourself; you'll see what I mean.)

The story of this game is short (about 10 mins) but solid in my opinion. You should appreciate what you have. Not everyone is lucky to have e.g. a father or a mother. 41705739.review:
While the visual novel is rather simplistic, it has an interesting concept, [spoiler] Ai turning out to be an well.. ai because the main character was lonely. [/spoiler] I hope if they do ever make a future work with the same kind of concept they explore more into the "whys" when it comes to the motivation of the main character. Overall, I enjoyed it and hope to see Eyzi make more and better visual novels. The visual novel is very simple and I wish it was developed more. But, it's free and, considering this is the only game I can find under Moonlit Work's name, I'm assuming it's a first attempt at a vn, or, at least ,the first vn of theirs they've released. Keeping that in mind, it makes sense why it's simple and it's a pretty good first attempt. 

However, as they move on to bigger projects and get better at creating visual novels, writing stories, and start selling their work, I'll be a lot less lenient when it comes to character development and the story (for example, in this visual novel it'd would have been nice if it was longer and explored the life of the main character and his motivations). But, for a free visual novel that seems to be a first attempt it's alright. It's nothing big but it's cute and fun and I enjoyed my time playing it, even if it was short. So, I'd recommend it. It's an enjoyable short experience and it's free so you don't really lose all that much from giving it a try.

41201342.review:
Completadas TODAS las escenas, LOGRO final obtenido

Novela visual extremadamente corta sin apenas puntos de elección que nos presenta una cita entre Ai y su novio. Como jugador tienes el papel de novio, pero tranquilo, no es un juego que pase más allá de un sentimiento romántico que no consigue narrar bien del todo. Moralista, la novela pretende inducir a la reflexión sobre el “Carpe Diem” y temas relacionados que no puedo explicar para no hacer spoiler. Pero fracasa completamente al tener una trama mal atada que carece de todo interés.

Gráficos y Tecnología >>> POBRE + 0,7 puntos

Tan sólo la protagonista femenina Ai tiene dibujo en esta historia. Su diseño es bonito pero como muchas visuals animé ya está muy visto, además, apenas tiene cuatro cambios de expresiones faciales y resulta demasiado estática. Pero el problema del diseño del juego es con los escenarios y las acciones narradas, o tiene demasiada narración o demasiadas pocas ilustraciones, y atendiendo al hecho que muchas acciones distintas pasan sin cambiar la imagen de fondo... hubo desgana para ilustrar el juego, parece un libro más que una visual novel. Puntúa algo por ocupar solamente 111 Mb, pero pudo ser mucho mejor.

Historia y Niveles >>> MUY MAL  0 puntos

Solo hay una decisión en el juego, y cambia un poco el recorrido para llegar al mismo final sin ningún cambio. Hay solamente tres recorridos posibles, y cada vez que juegas visitas dos.. muy mal, la novela incluso leída despacio dura diez minutos, aunque se esfuerza por que empaticemos con los personajes no lo consigue y el final aunque sorprendente lo es por tramposo, abusando de situaciones que lo hacían imposible (atentos a como Ai interacciona con lo que VE, por ejemplo). Final mal resuelto, historia demasiado corta, se supone una visual novel pero saca un CERO en el apartado de historia, nada más que decir.

Música y Sonidos >>>  MUY MAL 0 puntos

No hay efectos de sonido a pesar que suceden acciones que podrían incluirlos, al menos prediseñados, pero lo peor es que la historia se ameniza con un bucle musical de fondo un poco cansino y molesto que se beneficia de la corta duración del juego. Otro aspecto descuidado y hecho con prisas, la banda sonora no ha recibido atención alguna por parte del desarrollador.

Control y Jugabilidad >>> BIEN ! + 1,5 puntos

Mal común en Steam, reciclar motores de visual novel de unos juegos a otros para otorgar solidez y funcionalidad a cambio de perder originalidad y méritos. Como muchas visuals, utiliza una base prediseñada de controles para ese tipo de juegos que incluye buenos controles de avance y omisión de texto, guardar y cargar partidas... lo típico. Funciona correctamente y dado que el juego tiene una duración escasísima y nula rejugabilidad, cumple con su cometido. Además, un entorno limpio de bugs ni problemas, además de disponer la historia en varios idiomas, hacen que Carpe Diem puntúe alto en este apartado.

Integración en Steam >>>  BIEN ! + 1,5 puntos

Existe un logro por finalizar la historia, es necesario (penalizo las visuals sin ningún logro ya que Steam no las cuenta nunca como completadas) pero la descripción del logro tiene un brutal spoiler (si no lo has leído, no lo hagas). Como juego gratuito no puede tener Cromos de Steam, y los marcadores no tendrían sentido. No obstante, debo bonificar su coste cero ya que invita a vivir su experiencia al menos una vez, sin perder nada por ello.

CONCLUSIÓN FINAL >>>  3,7 desarrollador, qué estás haciendo con tu vida?

Después de leer mi análisis reflexionad que tan malo debe ser el juego para que aún siendo GRATIS y funcionando bien mecánicamente ni siquiera alcance el 4 sobre 10. ¿vale la pena leer Carpe Diem? Siendo gratis te diré que da lo mismo, si te sobran diez minutos lo lees y si no no, no tiene más interés. El final parece además una especie de burla por jugar el juego en sí. ¿qué podían haber hecho? Dibujar más, o poner más ocpiones, o hacer un final COHERENTE con los hechos de la trama, o reforzar que nos importe algo más que cero Ai y su novio... No lo juegues, es desperdiciar tu vida como el desarrollador insinúa.

pd. Hay un DLC de pago para apoyar al desarrollador? en serio? Qué cara. NO LO COMPRES.

40978595.review:
A very nice free to play kinetic (that means, you won't have to choose between dialogues but read only, like a.. novel on the PC xD) visual novel that of course I forgot through the years to positively review.
I really loved it back then and I'm loving it the same right now!
The thing that I didn't see back in the days is the DLC - for just 1€/$ you can support the developers and buy an extra package which will give you all the background images, artwork, soundtrack and some other small extras. 
Definitely worth its price! :)
Back to the game, well, when you see that it had 10.000 reviews or little less, there aren't many words to add. 
For sure it's very short, but pleasing under every aspect - nice artwork and backgrounds, good music, and a simple but enjoyable plot that will require you half an hour of reading and relax :)
It's not a life changer, but it will definitely have its importance with the bond that you'll create with the main character.
So, we'll play as a young boy called Jung - I forgot to mention that this game, being so famous, has also lots of translations but I keep on playing them all in English - and you'll see everything under his perspective. 
He's sort of a calm guy who'll encounter Ai, the female protagonist of the story, whose name also means "love" in Japanese among the other meanings if I remember well, but anyways.. that's of course the point of change.
She'll somehow manage to make Jung's life a little different, and the two of them are definitely a nicely developed and written thing together.
So, there'll be anyways in such a little time many deep meanings connected to Ai's life and her role in the novel and in every way you and her will behave during the small novel.. ok, it won't be your choice, but it'll be nice and touching xD
The message that this indie developer wanted to convey relies in the novel's title - carpe diem, which for an Italian like me is something we often hear, and it means something like, seize the present, catch the moment, do the right thing in the small lapse of time the nature's given to us.. diem stays for "day" of course, carpe, "capture", "pick", and even "make use of"..
And I really didn't find that convincing the other view that many reviewers took - like, if this game wanted to make us think what we're doing with our life with a precise link to Steam and computer gaming in general.
I'd prefer to stick with the game's artwork, Jung+Ai relationship/bond and everything in-game, without trying to find other meanings.
It's a very short and free visual novel, the DLC is worth the price, and it should be enjoyed as it is. If you like to draw your conclusions, that's great.
And anyways, I really recommend it.
It may be sad. It may be relatable for what concerns the whole computer/"otaku" thing, the "girlfriend".. you'll see what I mean in a couple of minutes, anyways.
It's a great visual novel, it's deep, it has limited but nice artwork and should be taken as it is, nor glorified neither too regardless criticized.
And then, you can go on with the second part of this visual novel.. way longer and improved.. if you had liked of course all the meanings of this one and all the "virtual" setting that's relatable and matches what we're living, maybe :P

This game is about a guy named jung who is meeting up with his "girlfriend" for the first time in a while. You get to choose various places for you two to visit and hang out at. [spoiler] But in the end, you will always end up with the same ending	[/spoiler]


To be honest, this game is not that bad for a free game that's only about 50MB in size, but it does lack in diversity of plot. The character build up is a bit lacking since you wont feel as immersed with the characters as deep as you would at major visual novels, and the "plot twist" at the end isn't really that much surprising or in other words, "guessable". Other than that, this game also has the same soundtrack repeated over the course of the whole gameplay, except for the ending which plays a different soundtrack which is nice but can also be a bit boring after a while.

But in the end, this game offers you about 10 minutes of gameplay with nothing much going on, so if youre just someone that has nothing else better to do and wanted to check this game out, then do so. But i wouldn't really recommend this game to poeples who are really into visual novels and are searching for a truly immersive experience.

38370180.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Carpe Diem is a very, very short Indie visual novel that's pretty fresh in terms of story but the game itself is very short that can be completed in less than an hour or even less.

[h1]Story(NO SPOILERS) & Gameplay[/h1]
In the visual story, you play as Jung, your typical everyday adult guy who has a date with a her ideal woman, Ai, who has everything he wishes for in a woman. Storywise, it's pretty decent and solid but to others and newcomers, it may feel like the story is rushed and not much story-branching is not really impacting the story especially when the ending does not change at all (as mentioned on the store page). Some players might also feel that, the ending, although sad to hear, feels abrupt and out of nowhere. For the developer's first step, it's a fine step (coming from someone who doesn't develop games LOL) for the developer, however visual novel die-hards may find this to be rushed. Overall, story is fine except that it can feel really short and abrupt, especially towards the ending. And no, the ending does not in a cliffhanger so you don't need to play the sequel, Carpe Diem:Reboot.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Visuals look pretty good, especially for the developer's first visual novel.The colours give the locations a personality and definetely make Ai look very pretty. Other than that, there's not too much to say for a game that's very short, So yeah, visuals look good and nice.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The music sounds very calming and relaxing. However, after listening to a couple of times, it may get pretty repititive and somewhat annoying. There isn't much in terms of music. 3 Soundtracks in total: Main game, ending and the menu (I think, if there's one;cant remember lol). Overall, nice music but can get pretty reptitive (which shouldn't be the case for a very short game).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Carpe Diem is a solid direction for the developer's first visual novel, which makes it interesting for casual visual novel players to join. However, its short story and abrupt ending can turn serious visual novel players off. But regardless, it shows a message to players that it is important to keep your 
priorities to your loved ones.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+Nice visuals
+Relaxing soundtrack

36937467.review:
Carpe Diem:
A very cool short game with a nice twist in the end. Looks simple but has a deeper meaning. Multiple choices are a nice way to extend the gameplay hours. The music is soothing, in fact, I pop it up just for the music sometimes. Buying the soundtrack is highly recommended if you would like to listen to some calming music and supporting a creative developer in the process.

Gameplay: Smooth & simple dialogue based interactive comic-book/anime style.
Graphics: Polished 2D anime-like. Looks gorgeous.
Music: Calm and melodious. 
Glitches?: None discovered so far.
Bang for buck?: Yes, because it's free and provides some good insight into creative storytelling.
Suggested improvements?: Length could be longer but since it's free, I think we can expect it in a paid expansion. The choices, has effect on locations and dialogues, ultimately lead to a similar place.Also, more choices would have been nice.  Maybe the future title can add mulitple endings. Here, to have a good impact and to deliver a message, multiple endings seem to have avoided. Which was a good intention perhaps.
Overall: 4.5/5 Almost perfect for a short free game. Would love to see what the developer does with a sequel!
Give it a go and get awestruck at the end!

34848097.review:
This is a very short, cute visual novel, that will take you around 20 minutes to finish reading. It's fairly well written and I think it hints at some talent on the part of the author, but it's very obviously a "first attempt", very simple and minimalistic. As such, I rate it positively - while it didn't do anything that special, dialogues were simply amusing enough and the twist interesting enough that I (ironically) didn't regret the time spent with it.  

Also, there's a continuation of this game in development, so you should probably treat it as a short prologue and the idea/message it hints at will be expanded on in the future - I'm myself quite curious whether anything interesting will come out of it.

------------------------------

PS If you're interested in more quality western VNs, check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32980295/]my curator page[/url].

34474949.review:
Despite it's massive budget and experienced team of developers, DICE once again fails to rejuvinate the long-dead and over-stayed franchise. The game boasts 80+ hours of content, which leads me to believe that the developers had in mind quantity, over quality.

Characters will show up seemingly out of no where, no motivation, and will "die" but appear later on, when the story demands it. On a technical level, this game is very dissapointing. Characters will block entire views of the usually good looking landscapes. What was once a novelty becomes a distraction. 

The story can't help itself from collapsing upon itself during the second to third act. DICE is desperate to meet the usual story beats that of a blockbuster, setting up conflicts in which there is no time, effort, or emotion devoted to. Yet another example of triple A devs milking their franchise. When a story's opacity is so low that you can see the desperate money laundering thieves behind it, you know that the story is about to end, with a not so subtle " THUNK "! 

This series will always be remembered for pioneering RTS and Platforming as we know it. However, a table to stand on does not make the food on top of it good. 
If Ai has taught me anything, it's to avoid social interaction and talk with a retarded woman who cannot close up her own shirt. 

Such a shame. A game legendary for starting something revolutionary, yet ending with great relief. 

I give Super Mario brothers 2 for the N64 a 7/10, I am very dissapointed in this game.

33279193.review:
I don't know what to think about this game.

It's short, but the story manages to deliver an emotional message. The visuals are cute and the music matches the atmosphere. The game costs nothing so there seems to be no downside. Objectively everything is fine and I recommend to try it out.

It's just that personally I don't like the message it delivers. It criticises the whole "otaku and their waifu" thing and lures otakus in with a cute anime girl and the whole visual novel setup only to destroy their worldview.
Personally I don't think it's something bad having a waifu or multiple waifus. Only a very small percentage of otakus really overdo it with getting in debt because they need to buy ever single merchadise of her as a proof of love or cooking for two persons and so on.
Some otakus like a specific anime girl, buy 1-2 figures of her, but still perfer 3D over 2D. Other otakus prefer having a virtual girlfriend because it's too hard finding a real girlfriend in a society that judges people from the get go and everyone who isn't part of the norm gets excluded. Also people who have huge problems with social interaction due to some mental illness can usually only get comfort and affection through virtual girlfriends.

Either way a 2D waifu will make someone happy and as long no one is suffering, in my opinion there's nothing wrong with having a virtual girlfriend. So in the end it doesn't really matter if she's real or not.

33248529.review: Do you want to add an additional game to your “Perfect Games” counter? This is a game for you. Buy the $0.99 DLC if you want the game to be on your account forever. I was going to buy the DLC, but the game was just too annoyingly short and unsatisfying to justify it for me. There is only one opportunity to pick a “path” and it only changes what happens very slightly in the middle. The end is the same no matter what option you chose. No trading cards, very minimal effort on the creator’s part (ex: the character model doesn't change if you go to the mall and she tries on clothes), and a single achievement for playing the game to the end. I wish there was a “meh” option because I don’t want to give this a “thumbs up” or “thumbs down”. I guess thumbs up since now I have 8 perfect games.

32719923.review:
I know, I know, I'm not supposed to hold too high expectations for free games, especially when they are individually developed.

But this game does not have much to offer. With a fairly limited number of backgrounds, character arts, and soundtracks, it does not provide a satisfying gameplay. As such a short game, the plot is poorly developed (the useless and repetitive dialogue does not count) and the ending consequently appears very abrupt. 

The central message the game maker is trying to convey is made clear by the title: "Carpe Diem" -- enjoy it while it lasts. The short gameplay ([spoiler] the short life of Ai [/spoiler]) is a metaphor for life. Our life isn't really much longer than this short gameplay. 

And then, the game conveys another message through the game ending and the only achievement: [spoiler] What are you doing with your life? Should you really be spending time on Steam? [/spoiler]

The game reminds me a little of [spoiler] the greek story [i] Pygmalion [/i], where a king makes himself a sculpture of a perfect girl which he falls in love into. He came to treat the sculpture as a real girl, like kissing her everyday, etc. You get the idea. And then the great Aphrodite was moved and turned the sculpture into a real girl, and they had a good ending. [/spoiler] Similar stories are being developed in the internet era because of you-know-why, but this game, as one of them, does not explore it enough, if at all.

The game does trigger some thinking, which almost wants me to change my opinion from "No" to "Yes". But then again, the game is unqualified at its job: being a game. The fact that there are 10 pages of save slots amuses and bemuses me -- you don't need any.

The thank-you screen mentions that this is only the first project of the game maker. So maybe this game works as a test for the game mechanism, which explains the 10-pages save slots. I am expecting the next games of the game maker, and hopefully the mentioned problems will be solved. I suggest expanding your team.

Summing up, this is a poor game with a clear message. If you have a few minutes to spare I guess it doesn't hurt to play it. But again, it isn't really fun. It's a pity that there are no middle grounds in the review system of Steam, because that's where this game falls into.

4/10

I spent more time writing this review than playing the game.

31754490.review:
A recommendation for anyone trying this game for the easy 100% achievement win: first thing, go to Settings, find the text speed option, and set it to maximum. This will shave a few minutes off the time you need to spend playing... which is a good thing.

The game is a first attempt at a visual novel, and the creator makes a valiant attempt at a solid twist ending, but it ends up being a little too predictable/preachy for my taste. The relatively limited art assets, limited choices that have no real impact on the outcome, and writing that is readable but otherwise unexceptional make this one to skip, unless you're a perfect-game hunter.

31654809.review:
[h1]You may call it "Good movies gourmet" syndrome...[/h1] 
  But, as for me, this VN isn't even trying

  What did you say? [i]"U kent be so critikel cuz it iz free"?[/i]

https://youtu.be/mBet2BhlP-M
  Delivering a piece of bad content for free never made it and will never make it anyhow better


  And leaving out annoying music ("cuz it is fur free" doesn't work here either because you can access a lot better free music on the net) and unappealing art style (spending some time to practise with an "Anime artist in 5 steps" book wasn't an option either, I guess) lemme start with an obvious complaint:

  - [b]Lack of exposition[/b]
  Pushing a player into the story with no exposition and information is a good idea ONLY if it is executed properly later. The ending just pops out of nowhere, making little to no sense, because there's no (I mean it, NO) motivation stated. Did previous GF die in a car accident, cut her veins or was eaten by rabies hamsters? Is the protagonist an obsessed scientist or just a smart otaku? 
  Why the hell should I sympathize someone with no logical reasoning?
  Adding even a single flashback screenshot or a little item on the table would make everything MUCH better


Here is an unusual one:

  - [b]The title[/b]
  "Carpe Diem" can be translated from Latin as "seize the day"... Which makes no sense to me, taking a look at the plot
[spoiler]When did attempts to create an AI capable of passing the Turing test become a waste of your life? Does the creator realize what a breakthrough it will become or just use intelligent sounding words to... sound intelligent?[/spoiler]
  The original message (jumping back to the lack of exposition) would make MUCH more sense if I felt ANY emotional impact and knew the motives. But at this state, a single question "Why combining science and girly girls wouldn't work?" ruins everything

 [i]"But hey, bro, take a closer look at the title, that's some smart move"[/i]

 Just like the Wachowskis' lazy letters juggling in Matrix Revolutions with "Mobil Ave" being an anagram for "Limbo"? No, it isn't
 There are loads of much smarter visual symbolism examples in movies and games

 [i]"But the protagonist's name gives us..."[/i]

 *sigh*
 Putting the name "Jung" and some symbols and references together gives you nothing, but a reference to Carl Jung's theory. Does it affect or improve the story and characters? Or is it somehow speculated on?


 - [b]Uninteresting story telling[/b]
  Dialogs are the core of any VN (Captain Obvious breaks in through the window)... And they are lame. There is no effort put into them. Location A, useless talking; location B, useless talking; location C, the ending right in your face. Even 20 minutes long talking could have been improved even a little bit by adding several intriguing or serious moments during the conversation.

  [h1]TL; DR[/h1] Wunderbar concept ruined by lazy attempt
  A true waste of time, as the achievement states, even "fur free"

29485957.review:
This VN is incredibly short and I find myself unable to really talk about it without spoilers. Beware.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ It's free and short so you won't lose anything if you try it out
+ Decent art, nothing amazing but okay
+ Easy to 100% if that's something that's important to you

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Lack of variety in art, you'd think that in a short game there would've been time to focus on giving more than what was delivered
- Takes arguably tasteless jab at its target demographic

[b]Final Verdict:[/b] ☆☆☆☆☆★★★★★ 
5/10 - Average 
What starts out as seemingly cute VN about a couple out on a date ends up using the classic “none of this is real” gimmick on you toward the end when the VN your character is playing crashes and he is left to ponder his life choices. It's understandable that people would be offended by how the game decided to address its target audience by directly shaming you for playing it (even in the only achievement of the game) and it does reek of an attempt to be smarter than it actually is. For this reason I can understand people being angry but I personally wasn't as I like that sort of twist, and the length was so short that you didn't feel like you lost anything by going through it. Admittedly if this had taken up more time to make the same point, then I would have definitely rated it lower. 

I don't recommend this per se, but Steam has yet to implement an option for you to remain neutral so I decided to give this a thumb up.

La verdad cuando empece a jugar esta novela visual me esperaba otra cosa, me esparaba un videojuego pero Carpe Diem no es un videojuego, realmente no juega nada con el principio basico de todo videojuego, la interacción. Esta historia seria mucho mejor si lo que estuvieramos viendo fuera una serie o pelicula.

SPOILER ALERT
Pasando a lo que importa de verdad, la historia. La historia es practicamente una cita, ni mas ni menos, es mu simple, pero lo que lo hace destacable, es que la chica, es lo que se puede ser la chica perfecta, por lo visto en el poco tiempo con el que esta Novela Visual cuenta no hay nadie que no quisiera salir con ella. Y es por eso que no existe, ni en la vida real, ni en la novela. 
Los 12 minutos que me tomo terminarla fueron una completa perdida de tiempo pero no lo digo en un mal sentido, el autor la escribio con esa intención, el queria que perdieramos el tiempo. El protagonista es igual a mi y a muchas personas, aunque no sepamos nada de él, podemos imaginar que es igual a muchos de nosotros. Y por nosotros me refiero a todos esos frikis que nunca han tenido novia, esta es una historia esta dedicada a esas personas pues la tipa protagonista es la chica soñada para muchos. Pero sabemos que eso no es posible, el final lo deja bastante claro, el final donde vemos que el protagonista es un chico mirando a una computadora lo deja bastante claro. El mensaje que deja Carpe Diem, es que no seamos idiotas y no malgastemos nuestra vida, imagianando tener una relación con un tipo de chica que es imposible que exista.

Pero aunque todo lo que acabo de decir es muy interesante no la puedo recomendar porque realmente no es una buena historia. Su problema es que es muy simple y limitada, tiene un punto interesante, pero no aprovecha las cartas que tiene a su favor y se quedo la experiencia simple que es.

I really don't think the message of this game is actually meaningful at all. Don't most people who play visual novels already know that the characters aren't real? The point of a game is that it's entertaining and passes the time between work and sleep. Some people are actually satisfied with this kind of lifestyle because what you value in life is subjective. If someone else wants to go have real relationships then that's fine, but not everyone wants that. Then there are people like me who do a little of both, so the message is useless because I already do what the game's dev wants me to do. So who is this directed at? No matter who it's meant for, it fails to send a meaningful message. 28353311.review:
In this very short visual novel, you play as Jung, a young man who goes out on a date with his girlfriend, Ai.

If that one sentence introduction is any indication, this is an extremely short game. There are only three "routes" in the game and all of them lead to the same ending. I suppose the main purpose of the game is the twist ending, but I will avoid spoiling it.

Overall, this was a lame attempt at a visual novel. There is hardly any content at all, no real story, bland artwork, and most of the game has a single short music track that plays on a loop. The dialogue is horribly written and sounds way too stilted to resemble any actual conversation. The length of the game is almost a joke. Even with three routes, this game took me about twenty minutes to get completely through. I really am not sure who the target audience for this is supposed to be, but for me, I was thoroughly unimpressed.

Overall, despite the short length, I thought this was a poor attempt at a visual novel and not worth the time.

[h1][b][u]Carpe Diem Review - Rating: 1.4/10[/u][/b][/h1]

[h1][b]General Impression[/b][/h1]
[quote]Carpe Diem… live the moment… more like live the wasted time. What the hell? Some poor written scenarios? That’s it? The graphics and the textures are simple and neat. The atmosphere happens in 3 places: mall, park and arcade. Each one of them has 3 scenarios, but all of them has the same uncreative ending. The audio and the music are decent. The gameplay is very poor, all you have to do is to click further and further on the dialogues… ha, ha, ha. The story… is an epic failure. Won’t even comment about it. The user interface is simple and OK. The controls are very simple too, just your mouse is needed. The engines are alright, I haven’t found any haven’t met any bugs, crashes, screen freezes or frame drops. The mechanics are very simple, and cartoonish style. I don’t like them. Overall, Carpe Diem is a game which is worth skipping, unless you want to get the achievement and get one more 100% achievements game (all you need to do is to finish a scenario).[/quote]

24209286.review:
(spoiler free review)

[h1] TLDR - 9/10 (Awesome story, great characters, extremely short, minimal interaction, movie-like experience, FREE)[/h1]

[h1] Main Review [/h1]
Obviously, making a "full review" on a game like this one is quite hard. But, i'll give it a try. I haven't played many visual novels in the past, but after Carpe Diem I'm seriously considering them. Quoting Wikipedia "Carpe diem is a Latin aphorism, usually translated "seize the day", taken from book 1 of the Roman poet Horace's work Odes". And it means that you have to live for the present, to make the most of your time. At least that's what i got from googling.

It took me exactly 12 minutes to finish the game. I guess I'm a fast reader, because most people say it took them more than 20 minutes. There is no interaction besides pressing [space], [enter] or left-clicking to progress through the dialogue. Oh, actually there is one point, near the start of the game, where you get to choose where you wish to go. From that point, the story unfolds in three different ways, each and one of them being slightly different from the others. The simplicity of that brings lots of haters who complain that these kind of games aren't even games. I disagree, because they are meant to be like that. A different movie-like experience. Moving on, the game also has a save system. I really appreciate the fact that the devs included it, even though i didn't use it a single time (like most of us). Apart from those, there aren't many noteworthy mechanics.

So, the game is mainly focusing on the two main characters, the boy and the girl. The boy, who remains unnamed and the girl named Ai meet at the park. The dialogue seems fluid between them and you can easily get attached to the characters. On that matter, it's more likely that you'll start attaching yourself to Ai, because she's the only one whose face is shown in the game. It gives the feel that you're participating in the events through the eyes of the male character, because Ai is always facing the player. The visuals are great, i personally love the arwork. Aside all that, what really matters are the characters themselves. The development is great, but if were given more time to understand the characters it would be awesome. Within the range of 15 minutes, it's hard to make something really good. But, by giving us a taste of what the characters seem to be and then, twisting the reality that we were slowly getting into is... awesome! I loved the twist at the end and i believe it's one of the main reasons that people loved this game.

[h1] Good Points [/h1]
- Nice visuals
- Saving system
- Awesome plot and character development
- Value for price (free!)

[h1] Bad Points [/h1]
- Too short
- Not much interaction compared to other similar games

23827995.review:
The fact that this game is 5-10 minutes long works to its advantage, because the sudden stop of an ending is the entire point. I mean, just imagine how furious you'd be if this were 10 hours or more, and then all of a sudden they drop that on you.

Rather than let you get attached to its characters and *then* make you sad for them, it's kind of inverted: You don't get a chance to get attached to anyone, and that in itself makes it sad. It's like it leaves you out of the world on purpose, and that's where the emotional impact is. Which is actually kind of creative, and it works.
